questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of colicky abdominal pain and vomiting. He also had a sore throat 2 weeks ago. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. Examination of the lower extremities shows nonblanching raised erythematous papules. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Bowel sounds are high-pitched. Both ankles are swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
9800/mm3



Platelet count
265,000/mm3



Serum



 Glucose
78 mg/dL


 Antinuclear antibodies
negative


Urine



 Glucose
negative


 Protein
negative


 Blood
2+


 RBC

10–12/hpf with dysmorphic features


 WBC
0–1/hpf


Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows a portion of the bowel with alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands in transverse view. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

choices.text: Incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Goodpasture syndrome is due to autoantibodies against type IV collagen (found in renal and pulmonary capillary basement membranes) that can cause nephritis, as seen in this patient. However, intussusception and purpura are not common features of Goodpasture syndrome. Instead, these patients typically have lung findings (e.g., hemoptysis, cough, dyspnea).

B) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis is a type of p-ANCA-positive vasculitis of small vessels that can manifest with arthritis, abdominal pain, and purpura. However, most patients have a history of constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss). Furthermore, this condition most commonly affects adults; children with this same constellation of symptoms are more likely to have a different type of vasculitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) causes the formation of microthrombi within small vessels, which may cause purpura and renal dysfunction, as seen here. However, HUS is classically seen in children with a diarrheal illness with EHEC (usually type O157:H7) and is characterized by the presence of hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia. Arthritis and intussusception are not associated with HUS.

D) INCORRECT:

Incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct leads to the development of Meckel diverticulum. Although most patients with Meckel diverticulum are asymptomatic, the omphalomesenteric duct remnant may create a nidus for intussusception, which can manifest with colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, and blood in the stool. However, intussusception due to Meckel diverticulum is rare and usually an isolated finding. Furthermore, Meckel diverticulum does not explain this patient's purpura, arthritis, and nephritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Sepsis from a gram-negative cocci infection with Neisseria meningitidis can cause renal dysfunction and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), resulting in palpable purpura, as seen in this patient. However, patients with meningococcemia are extremely sick with severe vital sign abnormalities (fever, hypotension, tachycardia), and intussusception is not a common complication of this disease. Additionally, patients with DIC typically present with thrombocytopenia, which is not seen here.

F) CORRECT:

Deposition of IgA immune complexes in the vascular walls is the underlying mechanism of immunoglobulin A vasculitis (IgAV). IgAV is most commonly preceded by a viral infection, which is presumed to trigger an increase in IgA production, consequent deposition of IgA immune complexes in vessels, and activation of the complement cascade. Involvement of the intestinal wall vessels results in intestinal wall edema and thickening, which may act as a nidus for intussusception, as seen here. Patients with renal-vessel involvement develop IgA immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis (IgA nephritis). IgAV is a clinical diagnosis that is based on the presence of palpable purpura, arthritis and/or arthralgia, gastrointestinal symptoms, and nephritis. Most cases of IgAV resolve spontaneously, and the standard of care is supportive therapy.

G) INCORRECT:

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis is an HLA-associated synovial inflammation that can cause arthralgias/arthritis in children, as seen here. However, findings of intussusception, purpura, and nephritis are not associated with this condition.

H) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is due to autoimmune production of IgG antibodies against platelet antigens (usually after a recent viral illness), which can cause purpura, as seen in this patient. However, CBC will show a low platelet count, often < 50 K/uL, whereas this patient's CBC is normal. In addition, ITP rarely causes renal dysfunction, myalgias, or abdominal pain, unless there are bleeding complications.
questions.hint: This child presents with colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, blood in the stool, and a target sign (alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands) on ultrasonography, all of which are consistent with intussusception. The combination of intussusception with palpable purpura on the lower extremities, bilateral arthritis of the ankle joints, and hematuria (indicating nephritic syndrome) are highly suggestive of a type of small-vessel vasculitis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 4-day history of arthralgia, abdominal pain, and lesions on his arms and legs. Ten days ago, he had an upper respiratory tract infection. A photograph of his right leg is shown. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Genital ulcers are a hallmark feature of Behcet disease, which can also present with skin lesions and arthralgias. However, Behcet disease typically causes painful oral ulcers and uveitis, not abdominal pain. In addition, the disease is most common in populations originating from Turkey, the Middle East, and China. Finally, genital ulcers are not an expected finding in Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

B) CORRECT:

IgA vasculitis is characterized by the following tetrad of clinical findings: palpable purpura, arthralgias, GI symptoms such as abdominal pain, and renal disease, most commonly manifesting as nephritic syndrome. It is hypothesized that the deposition of IgA immune complexes in vascular walls activates the complement system, thereby leading to vascular inflammation and damage. Involvement of the renal capillaries and mesangium frequently leads to hematuria, often with RBC casts.

C) INCORRECT:

A new heart murmur suggests subacute bacterial endocarditis, which can also present with arthralgias and skin lesions. However, this patient's skin findings are inconsistent with the clinical features associated with endocarditis (e.g., Osler nodes, Janeway lesions, and splinter hemorrhages). In addition, subacute bacterial endocarditis is more likely to occur after a dental procedure, not after an uncomplicated upper respiratory infection. Finally, a new heart murmur is not typical of Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

D) INCORRECT:

A tick bite is an important finding in Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF), which can present with abdominal pain and a rash. However, the rash is blanching and macular, and begins at the extremities and spreads to the trunk. In addition, RMSF presents with fever and flu-like symptoms and usually does not cause arthralgias. A tick bite is not commonly associated with Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

E) INCORRECT:

Conjunctivitis is a hallmark feature of Kawasaki disease, which can also cause a rash and abdominal pain. However, the rash is typically truncal and polymorphous and involves erythema of the hands and feet. In addition, Kawasaki disease often manifests with fever and mucositis, neither of which are present in this patient. Moreover, conjunctivitis is inconsistent with Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

F) INCORRECT:

Splenomegaly is a common finding in Still disease, which can manifest with joint pain, abdominal pain, and a rash. However, the rash is usually transient, migratory, and salmon–pink, unlike the rash seen here in this patient. In addition, Still disease is most common in children ages 2–4. Finally, splenomegaly is not a feature of Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

G) INCORRECT:

Thrombocytopenia is an important finding in hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), which can present with a rash following an illness. However, HUS is typically preceded by bloody diarrhea and then manifests with hemolytic anemia that can cause fatigue and jaundice, thrombocytopenia, and a petechial rash. Thrombocytopenia would not be expected in Henoch-Schonlein purpura.
questions.hint: The onset of abdominal pain, arthralgia, and purpura several days after an infection in a child < 10 years of age should raise suspicion of IgA vasculitis, also known as Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of an intermittent, diffuse abdominal pain. She has also had a nonpruritic rash on her legs and swelling of her ankles for 1 week. Two weeks ago, she had a sore throat, which was treated with oral amoxicillin. Examination of the lower extremities shows non-blanching, raised erythematous papules. The ankle joints are swollen and warm, and their range of motion is limited by pain. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 350,000/mm3. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is characterized by isolated thrombocytopenia and is the most common cause of bleeding diathesis in children. The etiology is unclear, but it is commonly associated with a previous viral infection of the upper airway. Although the patient possibly had viral pharyngitis (sore throat), she has a slightly elevated platelet count, which excludes the diagnosis of ITP.

B) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome (DRESS) can occur ∼ 1–8 weeks after pharmacotherapy. The reaction is characterized by eosinophilia, thrombocytopenia, fever, and rash and can also lead to multiple organ failure. Although amoxicillin can also cause DRESS, the patient here does not have fever, organ failure, or thrombocytopenia, making another diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute rheumatic fever is an inflammatory complication of group A β-hemolytic streptococcal (GAS) pharyngitis that usually occurs 1–5 weeks after the initial infection. Acute rheumatic fever is important to consider in this patient who recently had a sore throat; however, her medical history reveals that she was treated with amoxicillin, which normally prevents the development of acute rheumatic fever. Furthermore, this patient does not have carditis (valve lesions, abnormal EKG), neurological involvement (Sydenham chorea), or subcutaneous nodules, making another diagnosis more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with juvenile idiopathic arthritis present with joint pain and extraarticular manifestations such as rashes. To establish the diagnosis, patients must be < 16 years of age and have joint inflammation that lasts > 6 weeks. This patient has only had ankle swelling for one week. Additionally, intermittent abdominal pain and recent pharyngitis would not be expected with JIA.

E) INCORRECT:

Familial Mediterranean fever is characterized by recurrent episodes of fever and severe abdominal pain that are occasionally accompanied by monoarthritis and skin manifestations. Although this patient has intermittent abdominal pain, she does not have fever or a family or ethnic history consistent with this diagnosis.

F) CORRECT:

Leukocytoclastic vasculitis is an umbrella term for vasculitides, including Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP). HSP is an acute immune-complex mediated vasculitis of the small vessels that is often preceded by an upper respiratory infection. The patient's history of pharyngitis 2 weeks ago and palpable purpura with arthritis and abdominal pain are classic signs of HSP. HSP can also present with bloody stools or occult bleeding (as in this patient) but is accompanied by a normal platelet count.

Supportive treatment is indicated in mild cases (as in this patient) and includes pain management, as the disease is usually self-limiting. Less commonly, patients develop a more severe form of the disease with renal involvement (increased creatinine, hematuria, and/or proteinuria), which requires treatment with systemic glucocorticoids.

G) INCORRECT:

Patients with meningococcal septicemia are severely ill, have high fever, and typically develop a petechial or purpuric rash and organ failure. Although this patient has likely not yet received a meningococcal vaccine (not routinely given to children in the US < 11 years of age) and is thus at increased risk of infection, she only has a purpuric rash, without high fever or organ failure, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.
questions.hint: This child's abdominal pain, arthritis, and raised rash are indicative of immune complex deposition disease.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 6-day history of pain in his knees, mild nausea, and a nonpruritic rash on his legs. Two weeks ago, he had a sore throat and mild fever treated with penicillin. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and he takes no routine medications. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. A photograph of the rash is shown. Serum creatinine concentration is 0.8 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

IgAV develops as a result of immune complex deposition in the vascular walls, which causes small vessel vasculitis, submucosal hemorrhage, and edema in the gastrointestinal tract. The thickened bowel wall can form a pathologic lead point for intussusception, which in IgAV is typically ileoileal and limited to the small bowel. Other complications of IgAV include small bowel infarction and perforation, and, in the case of renal involvement, IgA nephritis, which in severe cases may progress to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. In most cases, however, IgAV is uncomplicated and self-limited, and supportive therapy and monitoring for complications are a sufficient initial treatment approach in patients like this one.

B) INCORRECT:

Adrenal insufficiency can develop from adrenal hemorrhage as a complication of infection with endotoxin-producing bacteria such as N. meningitidis (i.e., Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome). Meningococcal meningitis can manifest with a purpuric rash over the lower extremities, as seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks other characteristic features of meningococcal meningitis such as fever, headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status. IgAV is not associated with adrenal insufficiency.
Image Description:

There are multiple small, nonblanching purple macules on the upper thigh, medial aspect of the knee, and anterior lower leg.

This appearance is consistent with purpura due to Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Thrombocytopenia in a child who recently had an infection and now presents with a purpuric rash is indicative of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). ITP is typically associated with viral infections, whereas this patient most likely had a bacterial infection, for which he was treated with an antibiotic. Furthermore, ITP does not manifest with arthralgia. IgAV is associated with a normal or increased rather than a decreased platelet count.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation (MR) can develop from acute rheumatic fever (ARF), a complication of infection with Group A streptococci (e.g., pharyngitis). ARF can manifest with arthralgia and a rash 2 weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis. However, skin findings in ARF usually also involve the trunk and show a pink or light-red rash with a well-defined outer border and central clearing (erythema marginatum), unlike what is seen in this patient. Furthermore, this patient received prompt treatment with penicillin for his pharyngitis, so manifestations of ARF (including MR) are unlikely. IgAV is not associated with MR.
Image Description:

Left upper arm of a child diagnosed with acute rheumatic fever (ARF)

Erythematous plaques with areas of central clearing are visible on the ventral aspect of the forearm.

This is characteristic of erythema marginatum, the characteristic annular erythema occuring in 10% of attacks of acute rheumatic fever in children, caused by group A streptococcus.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior uveitis can develop as a complication of systemic immune-mediated conditions. In a patient < 16 years of age with concomitant arthralgia in two weight-bearing joints (i.e., the knees), anterior uveitis should raise concern for juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), specifically for the subtype oligoarticular JIA. However, this condition does not manifest with a rash, and arthralgia would have to be present for > 6 weeks to establish the diagnosis. This patient has IgAV, another systemic immune-mediated condition, which is not associated with anterior uveitis.
questions.hint: The photograph shows a symmetric, coalescent, erythematous rash over both legs. In a child with arthralgia, mild gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea), and a history of an upper respiratory tract infection, this indicates IgA vasculitis (IgAV).

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of abdominal pain, nausea, and a progressively worsening rash on his legs for the past 5 days. He was well until 2 weeks ago when he developed a cough and a sore throat. These symptoms resolved spontaneously 1 week ago. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He appears well-developed and well-nourished. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the skin shows clusters of nonblanchable, erythematous papules on the lower extremities. There is mild, diffuse tenderness to palpation of the abdomen; no masses are palpated. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.2 g/dL


Leukocyte count
12,500/mm3



Platelet count
335,000/mm3



Prothrombin time
12 sec (INR = 1)


Partial thromboplastin time
35 sec

60 mm/h


Serum



 Urea nitrogen
15 mg/dL

0.7 mg/dL


Urine



 Blood

1+


 Protein
none


 RBC

6/hpf

1/hpf


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the abdomen may be the appropriate initial test in patients with marked abdominal symptoms or suspected complications of IgAV (e.g., intussusception). However, abdominal ultrasound is commonly the preferred initial test in children. In this patient with mild, diffuse tenderness to palpation of the abdomen, imaging is not indicated at this point.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral glucocorticoids are used in patients with IgAV for treatment of severe abdominal and/or joint pain not relieved by acetaminophen or NSAIDs. IV methylprednisolone pulse therapy is indicated in patients with severe renal involvement. This patient has mild, diffuse tenderness to palpation of the abdomen, so glucocorticoids are not indicated at this point. Acetaminophen and/or NSAIDs should be administered instead.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal biopsy is an invasive procedure that is generally only performed in cases where the definitive diagnosis is uncertain or to assess the severity of IgAV nephritis in patients with severe renal involvement (proteinuria > 1 g/day and/or impaired kidney function). This patient, however, has minimal renal involvement (hematuria, no proteinuria, and normal creatinine) and renal biopsy is, therefore, not indicated at this point.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum ANCA titers (e.g., p-ANCA, c-ANCA) are typically increased in small-vessel vasculitides such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis, microscopic polyangiitis, and eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis. ANCA-associated small-vessel vasculitides can manifest with palpable purpura and/or renal involvement. However, these conditions rarely affect children and most patients have a history of constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise, weight loss). Serum ANCA titers are typically negative in IgAV.

E) CORRECT:

Typically, IgAV (Henoch-Schonlein purpura) is a self-limited disease that only requires observation, supportive care (e.g., NSAIDs, rest, hydration), and outpatient follow-up. Kidney disease is seen in approx. 50% of cases. In patients with isolated hematuria, as seen here, monitoring of renal involvement with serial urine dipsticks is sufficient. Patients with a severe clinical presentation (e.g., inability to maintain oral hydration, severe abdominal pain, significant gastrointestinal bleeding, mental status abnormalities, severe arthralgia, severe renal disease) require inpatient treatment with systemic glucocorticoids, IV hydration, and blood pressure management. Patients with nephritic syndrome (IgA nephritis) and/or proteinuria also require monitoring of serum creatinine; in severe cases (e.g., proteinuria > 1 g/day and/or impaired kidney function) kidney biopsy may be indicated.

F) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immunoglobulin is used in the treatment of Kawasaki disease, a multisystemic acute vasculitis that, in children, can manifest with rash, gastrointestinal symptoms, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. However, patients with Kawasaki disease usually present with erythema and edema of hands and feet, including the palms and soles, and a polymorphous rash, rather than the palpable purpura on the lower extremities seen here. Moreover, hematuria is not typical, and this patient lacks other characteristic features of Kawasaki disease such as fever, conjunctivitis, adenopathy, and strawberry tongue.
questions.hint: Palpable purpura, gastrointestinal symptoms, and hematuria 1–3 weeks after an acute upper respiratory tract infection indicate immunoglobulin A vasculitis (IgAV), the most common systemic vasculitis in children. Leukocytosis and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate without thrombocytopenia or coagulopathy are typical.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man who works as a summer camp counselor is hospitalized with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, black diarrhea, a rash, and pain in his wrists, elbows, knees, and ankles. Three weeks ago, he was treated with amoxicillin for streptococcal pharyngitis. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use intravenous drugs.
The patient is afebrile, his heart rate is 82 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. He has a diffuse rash extending to the ankles (figure). There is no cervical, supraclavicular, axillary, or inguinal lymphadenopathy. Oral ulcers are not present. Periarticular swelling is noted around the ankles, wrists, and knees. No joint erythema or warmth is present. His mid-abdomen is tender to palpation without rebound or guarding. Rectal examination reveals dark hemoccult-positive stool in the rectal vault.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:

Urinalysis reveals no erythrocytes, leukocytes, or protein. Abdominal CT shows mild thickening of the duodenum.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Crohn disease can manifest as abdominal pain and diarrhea, but the most common skin findings are erythema nodosum, painful nodules (typically on the pretibial surfaces), and pyoderma gangrenosum, which manifests as large ulcers with undermined borders.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with disseminated gonococcal infection usually have either tenosynovitis or purulent arthritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Meningococcemia and disseminated gonococcal infection do not have prominent gastrointestinal manifestations. People with meningococcemia tend to be very sick and have associated fever and severe headache.

D) INCORRECT:

Cryoglobulinemia can manifest as palpable purpura, but gastrointestinal involvement is not prominent.

E) CORRECT:

Immunoglobulin A (IgA) vasculitis (formerly referred to as Henoch-Schönlein purpura) is a leukocytoclastic vasculitis that affects the skin, gastrointestinal tract, joints, and kidneys. About half of all cases are preceded by an upper respiratory infection, typically from streptococcus. This patient has the characteristic palpable purpura in the absence of thrombocytopenia.

The most common gastrointestinal symptoms of IgA vasculitis are abdominal pain and gastrointestinal bleeding caused by mucosal and submucosal hemorrhage. The small intestine is the most common site of gastrointestinal tract involvement. Intussusception, the most common surgical complication, occurs more in children than in adults.

Treatment of IgA vasculitis is generally supportive. Glucocorticoid use is controversial but may be beneficial for patients who are at high risk for kidney involvement and those with severe abdominal pain who do not respond to conservative measures.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a young man with palpable purpura, arthralgias, and abdominal pain after a streptococcal throat infection is immunoglobulin A vasculitis.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old woman presents with a rash, abdominal discomfort, and joint pain. She first noticed the abdominal discomfort one week ago and then developed worsening nausea 3 days ago. At the same time, she developed joint pain, particularly in her knees and ankles; now she feels like her legs are swollen. She has a rash that has become increasingly violaceous and confluent on her legs and buttocks, as well as around her elbows and her arms (figure).
She is currently afebrile, normotensive, and mildly tachycardic. Physical examination is notable for a distended and diffusely tender abdomen; a swollen, tender right wrist and left ankle; and bilateral moderate-sized knee effusions.
Laboratory evaluation reveals normal kidney function, mild thrombocytosis, and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein level. Antinuclear antibody, antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA), HIV, and cryoglobulin tests are negative, as is an acute hepatitis panel. A skin biopsy shows leukocytoclastic vasculitis.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Wegener's) can produce the same broad spectrum of organ involvement as microscopic polyangiitis, as well as additional features of destructive granulomatous inflammation, particularly in the upper airway and lungs. Approximately 30% of patients with disease limited to the airway are ANCA-negative, but about 90% of patients with systemic vasculitis test positive for ANCA.

B) INCORRECT:

Kawasaki disease occurs exclusively in children. Classic symptoms are persistent fevers, conjunctival injection, strawberry tongue, erythema of the palms and soles, and cervical lymphadenopathy. Vasculitis of the coronary arteries is common, but vasculitis in other organs is rare.

C) CORRECT:

Immunoglobulin A (IgA) vasculitis (a small-vessel vasculitis formerly referred to as Henoch-Schönlein purpura) occurs most often in children but does occur in adults and often follows an upper respiratory tract infection. The most common manifestations of IgA vasculitis are abdominal pain, arthritis, arthralgias, and purpura in dependent areas. Gastrointestinal vasculitis can result in bloody diarrhea. Skin biopsy usually reveals leukocytoclastic vasculitis; IgA deposition is seen with immunofluorescence. A subset of patients can develop a proliferative glomerulonephritis, which also stains positive for IgA deposition on immunofluorescence. Adults are more likely to develop chronic renal disease as a result of IgA vasculitis, whereas most children recover completely.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient who presents with abdominal pain, joint pain, and palpable purpura is immunoglobulin A vasculitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a vasculitis of small to medium-sized arteries and most commonly involves the skin, muscle, gastrointestinal tract, kidneys, and peripheral nervous system. There is an increased prevalence among patients infected with hepatitis B virus. The vessels involved in PAN are larger and deeper than the vessels in which vasculitis leads to palpable purpura; skin involvement in PAN usually manifests as livedo racemosa, deep cutaneous nodules, or ulcers.

E) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis is a multisystem vasculitis of small vessels. It could produce this patient’s combination of symptoms and signs, but the diagnosis is unlikely in the setting of a negative antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA).

questions.text:
A 31-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, a rash on his lower extremities, and pain in the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. The rash and joint pain started one week ago, accompanied by an hour of morning stiffness. The abdominal pain started 3 days ago. The patient was well until 4 weeks ago, when he developed an upper respiratory tract infection that resolved spontaneously.
Physical examination reveals diffuse abdominal tenderness without guarding or rebound, as well as tenderness of the bilateral metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints without swelling. The findings of the skin examination are shown (figure).
Laboratory testing reveals normal renal function, normal levels of complement proteins C3 and C4, negative findings for antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, and negative results for infection with hepatitis C virus.
Urinalysis reveals 1+ protein and 2+ blood, with 5 to 10 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2) on urine microscopy.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to be diagnostic for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Renal arteriography is unlikely to reveal abnormalities, given the small size of the involved vessels.

B) INCORRECT:

CT of the abdomen may reveal bowel-wall thickening or intussusception, but those findings are nonspecific.

C) INCORRECT:

An initial presentation with purpura and abdominal pain would be unusual in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Normal complement levels also argue against SLE, although not definitively, in a patient likely to have at least mild renal involvement. Above all, a positive antinuclear antibody test would not be sufficient to diagnose SLE in this case; positive testing for anti-double-stranded DNA or anti-Smith antibodies, or a characteristic finding on kidney biopsy, would be needed.

D) CORRECT:

Immunoglobulin A (IgA) vasculitis (formerly referred to as Henoch-Schönlein purpura) is a small-vessel vasculitis affecting the skin (palpable purpura), gastrointestinal tract, and kidneys (IgA nephropathy, which is usually mild but can be severe). It can be triggered by an upper respiratory illness or certain medications.

In children, IgA vasculitis is far more common than other vasculitides, so the diagnosis is usually made clinically. In adults, IgA vasculitis is much less common, so it is best to confirm the diagnosis by immunofluorescence examination of a skin-biopsy specimen, which would demonstrate immune complexes containing IgA in affected vessels. Having a high index of suspicion for IgA vasculitis is important when requesting an immunofluorescence study, as it requires two biopsy specimens.

Key learning point: A diagnosis of IgA vasculitis is best confirmed by immunofluorescence examination of a skin-biopsy specimen, demonstrating immune complexes containing IgA in affected blood vessels.

E) INCORRECT:

Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis does not affect the gastrointestinal tract as often as immunoglobulin A vasculitis does and is not triggered by respiratory viral illness. Furthermore, negative hepatitis C virus testing and normal complement levels make cryoglobulinemia less likely.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with several days of joint pain in her knees and ankles, as well as a fleeting rash on her lower extremities. She also reports a 2-week history of abdominal pain, intermittent bloody stools, and nausea, leading to decreased oral intake. She has had no recent infections, sinus disease, or asthma.
On examination, she appears moderately ill. Her temperature is 37.7°C, her blood pressure is 122/90 mm Hg, her pulse is 96 beats per minute, and her respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute. She has scattered, palpable purpuric lesions on her lower extremities. Her cardiac and pulmonary examinations are normal. Her abdomen is soft, with mild tenderness in the periumbilical area and lower quadrants bilaterally. Both of her knees are swollen and tender. The remainder of her joint examination is unremarkable. She has no focal neurological deficits.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
10.0
12.0–16.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
504,000
150,000–350,000


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (mm/hr)
98
1–25


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)

Her leukocyte count is 18,000 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000), with a normal differential. She has normal C3 and C4 complement and a negative antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody test. Urinalysis shows 2+ blood, no proteinuria, and no white cells.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Churg-Strauss syndrome) almost always features asthma and elevated circulating eosinophil levels. Sinusitis, neuropathy purpura or nodular skin lesions, and eosinophilic inflammation of the lungs are common, and the heart, gastrointestinal tract, brain, or kidney may become involved. Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies may be seen in half of patients with EGPA.

B) INCORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a vasculitis of small to medium-sized arteries. Symptoms result from ischemia of affected organs. The skin lesions reflect inflammation in larger and deeper arteries than those that cause palpable purpura, leading to nodules, ulcers, and/or livedo racemosa. The other most common manifestations of PAN are fever, weight loss, joint and muscle pains, neuropathy, kidney failure, intestinal angina, and, in men, testicular pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Cryoglobulinemia (the presence of circulating immunoglobulins that become insoluble at lower temperatures) is associated with plasma-cell dyscrasias (such as multiple myeloma and Waldenström macroglobulinemia), hepatitis C virus infection, and a variety of autoimmune diseases, such as systemic lupus erythematosus and rheumatoid arthritis. Complement depletion (particularly low C4) occurs in at least 80% of cases. Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis most commonly causes a purpuric rash, arthralgia, and neuropathy, but membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is also common, and a wide range of internal organs can be involved.

D) CORRECT:

Immunoglobulin A (IgA) vasculitis (formerly referred to as Henoch-Schönlein purpura) is a small-vessel vasculitis characterized by purpura, arthritis, abdominal pain, and hematuria. It is much more common in children than adults, but it is also an important component of the differential diagnosis of vasculitis in adulthood.

IgA vasculitis most typically manifests with rash (generally involving the lower extremities), subcutaneous edema, abdominal pain, joint pain (arthritis or arthralgia commonly affecting the hips, knees, or ankles), bloody stools, and, in men, scrotal edema. Approximately half of patients with IgA vasculitis have a preceding upper respiratory tract infection.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis for a young woman with abdominal pain, palpable purpura, and arthritis is IgA vasculitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis features a positive test for antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies in the great majority of cases, usually with specificity for myeloperoxidase. Arthralgia, myalgia, purpura, neuropathy, glomerulonephritis (often severe), and pulmonary vasculitis leading to hemorrhage are all common manifestations.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents with a rash and fatigue. He notes that he had a few days of sore throat, runny nose, cough, and fatigue about a month ago and that, one week later, he developed abdominal pain, diffuse muscle aches, and a bumpy red-purple rash over his arms, legs, and buttocks. During the past 2 days, he has been fatigued again and noticed that his urine is dark.
He has no significant medical history and does not have any medication allergies. He has been taking ibuprofen and acetaminophen for the muscle aches but takes no other medications.
He appears tired but is in no acute distress. His temperature is 36.8o C, his heart rate is 100 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg, his respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 98% while he breathes ambient air. Physical examination reveals a rash over his lower extremities (figure).
Laboratory testing yields the following results:

Serum immunoglobulin A (mg/dL)

60–337


Urinalysis is 3+ for blood and protein.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute interstitial nephritis is characterized by acute kidney injury and urine findings of white cells, white-cell casts, and sometimes eosinophils. It does not generally cause cutaneous vasculitis, although rash, fever, and nausea may be present. Arthralgias would not be typical.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s findings are most consistent with a diagnosis of immunoglobulin A (IgA) vasculitis (formerly referred to as Henoch-Schönlein purpura), which is one of the most common systemic vasculitides seen in children. IgA vasculitis tends to manifest with palpable purpura, diffuse abdominal pain, arthritis, arthralgia, hematuria, and/or proteinuria. Glomerulonephritis can occur in 30% to 50% of patients with IgA vasculitis, but most cases are mild. Glomerulonephritis in this setting is characterized by IgA deposition in the mesangium, subepithelial, and subendothelial spaces.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a child with abdominal pain, palpable purpura, and acute kidney injury is immunoglobulin A vasculitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is associated with either a toxic or ischemic insult to the kidneys and is typically diagnosed by the presence of granular casts in the urine sediment. This patient was taking ibuprofen, which can lead to ATN, but ATN is not associated with systemic symptoms such as arthralgia or palpable purpura.

D) INCORRECT:

Postinfectious glomerulonephritis often manifests as hematuria 2 weeks after an infection but is not associated with palpable purpura or other systemic symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Lupus nephritis is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Patients with lupus nephritis often have other features of SLE that predate the development of nephritis, such as joint pain, chest pain, facial rash in a butterfly distribution, and mouth sores.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy who works as a summer camp counselor is hospitalized with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, black diarrhea, a rash, and pain in his wrists, elbows, knees, and ankles. Three weeks ago, he was treated with amoxicillin for streptococcal pharyngitis. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use drugs.
The patient is afebrile, his heart rate is 82 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. He has a diffuse rash extending to the ankles (figure). There is no cervical, supraclavicular, axillary, or inguinal lymphadenopathy. Oral ulcers are not present. Periarticular swelling is noted around the ankles, wrists, and knees. No joint erythema or warmth is present. His mid-abdomen is tender to palpation without rebound or guarding. Rectal examination reveals dark hemoccult-positive stool in the rectal vault.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cryoglobulinemia can manifest as palpable purpura, but gastrointestinal involvement is not prominent.

B) CORRECT:

Immunoglobulin A (IgA) vasculitis (formerly referred to as Henoch-Schönlein purpura) is a leukocytoclastic vasculitis that affects the skin, gastrointestinal tract, joints, and kidneys. About half of all cases are preceded by an upper respiratory infection, typically from streptococcus. This patient has the characteristic palpable purpura in the absence of thrombocytopenia.

The most common gastrointestinal symptoms of IgA vasculitis are abdominal pain and gastrointestinal bleeding caused by mucosal and submucosal hemorrhage. The small intestine is the most common site of gastrointestinal tract involvement. Intussusception, the most common surgical complication, occurs more in children than in adults.

Treatment of IgA vasculitis is generally supportive. Glucocorticoid use is controversial but may be beneficial for patients who are at high risk for kidney involvement and those with severe abdominal pain who do not respond to conservative measures.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an adolescent with palpable purpura, arthralgias, and abdominal pain after a streptococcal throat infection is immunoglobulin A vasculitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Crohn disease can manifest as abdominal pain and diarrhea, but the most common skin findings are erythema nodosum, painful nodules (typically on the pretibial surfaces), and pyoderma gangrenosum, which manifests as large ulcers with undermined borders.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with disseminated gonococcal infection usually have either tenosynovitis or purulent arthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Meningococcemia and disseminated gonococcal infection do not have prominent gastrointestinal manifestations. People with meningococcemia tend to be very sick and have associated fever and severe headache.

questions.text:
A young woman, 19 years of age, presents with a rash, abdominal discomfort, and joint pain. She first noticed the abdominal discomfort one week ago and then worsening nausea 3 days ago. At the same time, she developed joint pain, particularly in her knees and ankles; now she feels like her legs are swollen. She has a rash that has become increasingly violaceous and confluent on her legs and buttocks, as well as around her elbows and her arms (figure).
She is currently afebrile, normotensive, and mildly tachycardic. Physical examination is notable for a distended and diffusely tender abdomen; a swollen, tender right wrist and left ankle; and bilateral moderate-sized knee effusions.
Laboratory evaluation reveals normal kidney function, mild thrombocytosis, and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein level. Antinuclear antibody, antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody, HIV, and cryoglobulin tests are negative, as is an acute hepatitis panel. A skin biopsy shows leukocytoclastic vasculitis.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Kawasaki disease is characterized by persistent fevers, conjunctival injection, strawberry tongue, erythema of the palms and soles, and cervical lymphadenopathy. Vasculitis of the coronary arteries is common, but vasculitis in other organs is rare.

B) INCORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a vasculitis of small to medium-sized arteries and most commonly involves the skin, muscle, gastrointestinal tract, kidneys, and peripheral nervous system. There is an increased prevalence among patients infected with hepatitis B virus. The vessels involved in PAN are larger and deeper than the vessels in which vasculitis leads to palpable purpura; skin involvement in PAN usually manifests as livedo racemosa, deep cutaneous nodules, or ulcers.

C) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis is a multisystem vasculitis of small vessels. It could produce this patient’s combination of symptoms and signs, but the diagnosis is unlikely in the setting of a negative antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA).

D) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Wegener's) can produce the same broad spectrum of organ involvement as microscopic polyangiitis, as well as additional features of destructive granulomatous inflammation, particularly in the upper airway and lungs. Approximately 30% of patients with disease limited to the airway are ANCA-negative, but about 90% of patients with systemic vasculitis test positive for ANCA.

E) CORRECT:

Immunoglobulin A (IgA) vasculitis (formerly referred to as Henoch-Schönlein purpura) is a small-vessel vasculitis that often follows an upper respiratory tract infection. The most common manifestations are abdominal pain, arthritis, arthralgias, and purpura in dependent areas. Gastrointestinal vasculitis can result in bloody diarrhea. Skin biopsy usually reveals leukocytoclastic vasculitis; if immunofluorescence is performed, IgA and complement C3 may be seen in the vessel wall. A subset of patients can develop a proliferative glomerulonephritis, which stains positive for IgA deposition on immunofluorescence.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a young adult who presents with abdominal pain, joint pain, and palpable purpura is immunoglobulin A vasculitis.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 6-year-old girl presents with a rash that began one week ago in association with a low-grade fever and malaise. Her parents report that she has been complaining of bilateral ankle pain and that her feet look puffy. She has had several episodes of emesis today and notes colicky abdominal pain. She is not taking any medications, and her family history is unremarkable.
On examination, she appears well but seems uncomfortable. She is afebrile and has normal vital signs for her age. Abdominal examination reveals diffuse tenderness to palpation without organomegaly. She has a nonblanching rash on her lower extremities (figure). There is bilateral swelling of the ankles and feet with normal range of motion and no overlying warmth or erythema.
Laboratory tests, including a complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel, are normal except for a platelet count of 650,000 per mm3 (reference range, 150,000–450,000) and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 30 mm/hour (0–20). Urinalysis reveals 10 red cells per high-power field (0–2).
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endoscopy would be appropriate in a patient with suspected inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Although this patient’s abdominal pain and arthropathy could raise suspicion for IBD, her purpura and hematuria are not typical manifestations of IBD. Although IBD can be associated with immune thrombocytopenic purpura, this type of purpura is associated with a low platelet count, not a normal to high one as seen in this patient. A more characteristic skin manifestation of IBD is erythema nodosum, which manifests with painful erythematous nodules, typically on the anterior surfaces of the lower legs.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is consistent with immunoglobulin A (IgA) vasculitis (formerly referred to as Henoch-Schönlein purpura), the most common childhood vasculitis. The annual incidence of IgA vasculitis is approximately 20 cases per 100,000 children and adolescents. The peak age of onset is between 4 and 6 years, and there is a slight male predominance.

For patients to be classified as having IgA vasculitis, they must have purpura or petechiae with a lower-limb predominance and at least one of the following:

• Arthritis or arthralgia
• Abdominal pain
• Skin biopsy showing IgA deposition
• Renal involvement (hematuria, proteinuria, or both)

Although the rash associated with IgA vasculitis is usually found on the legs, it can be present on any dependent area and can have associated deep bruising and ulceration.

Other than purpura, arthritis is the most common manifestation of IgA vasculitis, affecting up to 75% of children with IgA vasculitis. It typically involves the ankles and knees and is the presenting symptom in 15% of children with IgA vasculitis.

Gastrointestinal symptoms (typically abdominal pain and vomiting) are also common in IgA vasculitis, affecting 50% to 75% of children and preceding the purpura in up to 40% of patients.

Renal disease affects 20% to 60% of children with IgA vasculitis, with the most common manifestation being microscopic hematuria with or without proteinuria. Renal disease in IgA vasculitis typically develops within the first 6 weeks of symptom onset and rarely precedes the onset of rash.

There are no specific or diagnostic laboratory tests for IgA vasculitis. However, it is important to recognize that the platelet count will be normal, or even slightly elevated, despite the presence of a petechial or purpuric rash. Other inflammatory markers may or may not be elevated.

Treatment of IgA vasculitis is generally supportive. Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) may lead to symptomatic control of the arthritis and abdominal pain, as long as significant gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding and nephritis are not present. For many patients, however, glucocorticoids provide rapid relief of abdominal pain. These agents may shorten the duration of abdominal pain but do not change the clinical course or the risk of future nephritis, and patients may experience a flare as the medication is tapered.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for arthritis and abdominal pain in a child who has immunoglobulin A vasculitis without proteinuria or significant gastrointestinal bleeding is an oral glucocorticoid.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immune globulin (IVIG) has been used successfully in individual cases but is not considered first-line therapy given the paucity of a strong base of evidence. IVIG does have plausible mechanisms, however, which include Fc receptor saturation, anti-idiotype neutralization, and others.

D) INCORRECT:

An urgent kidney biopsy would not be necessary in this case, given the lack of proteinuria on urinalysis. Even for patients with nephrotic-range proteinuria, a kidney biopsy is not likely to be necessary given the likely findings of IgA immunofluorescence. In cases of rapidly rising creatinine levels or concern for crescentic glomerulonephritis, however, a kidney biopsy may help motivate selection of more aggressive therapies.

E) INCORRECT:

Plasmapheresis is considered first-line therapy for thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, a rare disease that is characterized by microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and profound thrombocytopenia. Fever is often present, and fluctuating neurologic symptoms are common. The disease can progress rapidly to renal failure. This patient does not have laboratory or neurologic findings to support this diagnosis.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a two-day history of purple, raised lesions on his buttocks and lower extremities after a recent sore throat. He also reports mild joint pains in his ankles and knees and colicky abdominal pain. He was previously healthy with no notable past medical history, and this is his first such episode. Examination shows non-blanching lesions, and there is no fever, lymphadenopathy, or hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory evaluation shows a normal platelet count and normal coagulation studies. Urinalysis reveals microscopic hematuria but no significant proteinuria.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is characterized by thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and often neurologic deficits. The normal platelet count and absence of hemolytic anemia in this patient do not support TTP. TTP is more common in adults, and the clinical presentation here aligns more with a vasculitic process.

B) CORRECT:

IgA vasculitis, also known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura, manifests with palpable purpura, often on the buttocks and lower extremities, following an upper respiratory tract infection. This condition involves IgA deposition in small vessel walls, leading to leukocytoclastic vasculitis. Systemic involvement includes joint pain and colicky abdominal pain due to vasculitis in the bowel wall. Renal involvement is indicated by microscopic hematuria without significant proteinuria, reflecting IgA deposition in glomeruli. The normal platelet count and coagulation studies support a vasculitic process rather than a coagulopathy or thrombocytopenia.

Key learning point: Henoch-Schönlein purpura (IgA vasculitis) is characterized by palpable purpura, arthralgia, abdominal pain, and often follows an upper respiratory infection in children.

C) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) involves immune-mediated platelet destruction, leading to thrombocytopenia and mucocutaneous bleeding. The normal platelet count and coagulation studies in this patient are inconsistent with ITP. Additionally, ITP does not typically present with joint pain, colicky abdominal pain, or microscopic hematuria.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum sickness–like reactions are typically triggered by medications, not infections. They present with urticarial rashes, unlike the palpable purpura seen here. The absence of recent medication exposure and the presence of colicky abdominal pain and microscopic hematuria suggest a vasculitic process rather than a serum sickness–like reaction.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with a 2-day history of a rash on his buttocks and lower extremities. Over the past week, he has had intermittent, crampy abdominal pain and multiple episodes of non-bloody, loose stools. He also reports intermittent knee pain, especially after activity. Examination reveals raised, non-blanching, reddish-purple lesions on both legs. Vital signs are normal. Laboratory studies show normal platelet count, normal prothrombin time, and normal activated partial thromboplastin time. Urinalysis reveals microscopic hematuria with occasional RBC casts.
Which of the following findings is most likely on biopsy of the affected skin?

choices.text: Fibrinoid necrosis of large vessels associated with multinucleated giant cells
Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody–mediated necrotizing vasculitis of small vessels
Granulomatous inflammation of medium-sized arteries involving the muscular layer
Leukocytoclastic vasculitis with immune complex deposition predominantly of immunoglobulin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fibrinoid necrosis with multinucleated giant cells indicates granulomatous inflammation of large vessels, as seen in giant cell arteritis. This pattern is inconsistent with Henoch-Schönlein purpura, a small vessel vasculitis characterized by IgA immune complex deposition and leukocytoclastic vasculitis, presenting with palpable purpura, abdominal pain, arthralgia, and renal findings in children.

B) INCORRECT:

ANCA-associated vasculitis involves necrotizing inflammation of small vessels, often in older patients with systemic symptoms and respiratory involvement. It lacks significant immune deposits (pauci-immune). In contrast, Henoch-Schönlein purpura in children presents with palpable purpura, joint pain, abdominal symptoms, and renal findings, indicating an immune complex–mediated vasculitis with IgA deposition.

C) INCORRECT:

Granulomatous inflammation in medium-sized arteries, involving activated macrophages and giant cells, is seen in vasculitides like polyarteritis nodosa or giant cell arteritis. This pattern does not align with the small vessel vasculitis and IgA deposition expected in Henoch-Schönlein purpura, which presents with palpable purpura, abdominal pain, arthralgias, and renal involvement in children.

D) CORRECT:

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), or IgA vasculitis, manifests with IgA immune complex deposition in small vessel walls, leading to leukocytoclastic vasculitis. This process involves neutrophilic infiltration and complement activation, causing inflammation in the skin, gastrointestinal tract, joints, and kidneys. Renal involvement, such as microscopic hematuria and red blood cell casts, results from IgA deposition in the glomerular mesangium. Immunofluorescence typically shows IgA and complement (often C3) along vessel walls, confirming the diagnosis. This immunologic cascade explains the pathology and clinical presentation of HSP in children.

Key learning point: Henoch-Schönlein purpura is a small-vessel vasculitis in children characterized by palpable purpura, abdominal pain, and sometimes joint pain.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents with a 3-day history of a raised, non-blanching rash on his buttocks and legs. He also has joint pains in his ankles and knees, and intermittent abdominal pain that wakes him at night. He is active and well-appearing overall. Physical examination reveals scattered purple lesions on the lower extremities. Laboratory evaluation shows normal platelet count and mild hematuria.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Renal biopsy is indicated for significant renal involvement, such as heavy proteinuria or rapidly worsening renal function. This patient has mild hematuria and normal renal function, suggesting self-limited renal involvement. Immediate biopsy is not warranted without severe renal findings.

B) INCORRECT:

High-dose intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) is used in conditions like Kawasaki disease or immune thrombocytopenia, not in IgA vasculitis. This patient's presentation, including purpura, joint pain, and mild hematuria, aligns with IgA vasculitis, where supportive care is preferred.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral corticosteroids are reserved for severe symptoms or significant renal involvement in IgA vasculitis. This patient has mild symptoms, including intermittent abdominal pain and mild hematuria, indicating a self-limiting process. Routine use of corticosteroids is not supported in uncomplicated cases.

D) CORRECT:

IgA vasculitis, formerly known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), is a small vessel vasculitis common in children. It manifests with palpable purpura on the buttocks and legs, joint pain, abdominal pain, and mild renal involvement, such as hematuria. The condition is usually self-limiting, and supportive care, including hydration, analgesia, and monitoring for complications, is the primary management strategy. This approach allows for early detection of severe renal or gastrointestinal complications that may require further intervention.

Key learning point: IgA vasculitis is an IgA-mediated vasculitis that presents with palpable purpura, arthralgia, abdominal pain, and renal involvement, and is primarily managed with supportive care.

Which of the following best explains the underlying pathophysiology of this child’s skin findings?

choices.text: Deposition of IgA-containing immune complexes in small vessel walls
Antibody-mediated platelet destruction leading to thrombocytopenia
Autoimmune targeting of hemidesmosomes in the basement membrane
Complement deficiency resulting in vascular endothelial damage

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Henoch-Schönlein purpura, also known as IgA vasculitis, is characterized by the deposition of IgA-containing immune complexes in small vessel walls. This process leads to leukocytoclastic vasculitis, manifesting as palpable purpura, particularly on the lower extremities and buttocks. The systemic nature of the condition is evident in joint pain, abdominal discomfort, and renal involvement, such as hematuria and mild proteinuria. The condition often follows an upper respiratory infection, which triggers the formation of IgA immune complexes, highlighting the connection between infection and the vasculitic process.

Key learning point: Henoch-Schönlein purpura (IgA vasculitis) is characterized by a tetrad of palpable purpura, arthralgia, abdominal pain, and renal involvement, commonly seen in children and adolescents.

B) INCORRECT:

Antibody-mediated platelet destruction, as seen in immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), results in thrombocytopenia and bleeding manifestations like petechiae. However, this patient has a normal platelet count, and ITP does not typically present with palpable purpura, joint pain, or gastrointestinal symptoms, which are indicative of a vasculitic process.

C) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune targeting of hemidesmosomes occurs in bullous pemphigoid, leading to subepidermal blisters, not palpable purpura. Bullous pemphigoid primarily affects the elderly, whereas this child presents with symptoms consistent with an immune complex-mediated vasculitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Complement deficiency can lead to immune complex deposition, but there is no evidence of complement deficiency in this patient. The presentation aligns with IgA-mediated vasculitis, where immune complex deposition and subsequent complement activation occur, rather than a primary complement deficiency.

questions.text: You are seeing an 8-year-old boy who is brought to your clinic with a 6-day history of knee pain, mild nausea, and a nonpruritic rash on his legs. Two weeks ago, he had a sore throat and mild fever, which was treated with penicillin. His medical history is unremarkable, and he does not take any routine medications. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.0°C, pulse is 95/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. A photograph of the rash is provided. Serum creatinine is 71 μmol/L (49–93). Urinalysis is normal. This patient is at increased risk for which one of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation (MR) can develop from acute rheumatic fever (ARF), a complication of infection with Group A streptococci (e.g., pharyngitis). ARF can manifest with arthralgia and a rash 2 weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis. However, skin findings in ARF usually also involve the trunk and show a pink or light-red rash with a well-defined outer border and central clearing (erythema marginatum), unlike what is seen in this patient. Furthermore, this patient received prompt treatment with penicillin for his pharyngitis, so manifestations of ARF (including MR) are unlikely. IgAV is not associated with MR.

B) CORRECT:

IgAV develops as a result of immune complex deposition in the vascular walls, which causes small vessel vasculitis, submucosal hemorrhage, and edema in the gastrointestinal tract. The thickened bowel wall can form a pathologic lead point for intussusception, which in IgAV is typically ileoileal and limited to the small bowel. Other complications of IgAV include small bowel infarction and perforation, and, in the case of renal involvement, IgA nephritis, which in severe cases may progress to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. In most cases, however, IgAV is uncomplicated and self-limited, and supportive therapy and monitoring for complications are a sufficient initial treatment approach in patients like this one.

Key learning point: IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura) increases the risk of intussusception due to bowel wall edema and submucosal hemorrhage from small vessel vasculitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Anterior uveitis can develop as a complication of systemic immune-mediated conditions. In a patient < 16 years of age with concomitant arthralgia in two weight-bearing joints (i.e., the knees), anterior uveitis should raise concern for juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), specifically for the subtype oligoarticular JIA. However, this condition does not manifest with a rash, and arthralgia would have to be present for > 6 weeks to establish the diagnosis. This patient has IgAV, another systemic immune-mediated condition, which is not associated with anterior uveitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Thrombocytopenia in a child who recently had an infection and now presents with a purpuric rash is indicative of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). ITP is typically associated with viral infections, whereas this patient most likely had a bacterial infection, for which he was treated with an antibiotic. Furthermore, ITP does not manifest with arthralgia. IgAV is associated with a normal or increased rather than a decreased platelet count.

E) INCORRECT:

Adrenal insufficiency can develop from adrenal hemorrhage as a complication of infection with endotoxin-producing bacteria such as N. meningitidis (i.e., Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome). Meningococcal meningitis can manifest with a purpuric rash over the lower extremities, as seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks other characteristic features of meningococcal meningitis such as fever, headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status. IgAV is not associated with adrenal insufficiency.
questions.hint: The photograph shows a symmetric, coalescent, erythematous rash over both legs. In a child with arthralgia, mild gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea), and a history of an upper respiratory tract infection, this indicates IgA vasculitis (IgAV).

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy presents with a 3-day history of a skin rash on his lower extremities, pain in both ankles, and mild abdominal pain. Examination shows a rash over the buttocks and legs (see image). Platelet count is normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) presents with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute renal failure, often after a gastrointestinal illness. The normal platelet count in this patient is inconsistent with HUS.

B) INCORRECT:

Acute rheumatic fever follows group A streptococcal pharyngitis and features migratory polyarthritis, carditis, and erythema marginatum. The purpuric rash and abdominal cramping suggest a small-vessel vasculitis, not acute rheumatic fever. The abscence of streptococcal infection history further makes this diagnosis less likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) involves immune-mediated platelet destruction, leading to thrombocytopenia and associated findings, such as petechiae. It typically presents with isolated cutaneous findings without systemic involvement. The normal platelet count excludes ITP.

D) CORRECT:

IgA vasculitis (IgAV; formerly known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura) is an IgA-mediated small vessel vasculitis common in children, characterized by palpable purpuric rash on the lower extremities and buttocks, joint pain, and abdominal cramping. Renal involvement (i.e., IgAV nephritis) is more common and usually more severe in adults than in children, typically manifesting with hematuria. IgA immune complexes deposit in vessel walls, causing inflammation and leakage of blood components, resulting in palpable purpura. While IgAV is a clinical diagnosis, laboratory studies are used to identify organ involvement and exclude differential diagnoses, and skin biopsy can confirm the diagnosis in patients with atypical presentations.

Key learning point: IgA vasculitis is characterized by palpable purpura, arthralgia, abdominal pain, and renal involvement, and is the most likely diagnosis in a child with a purpuric rash, joint pain, and abdominal symptoms with a normal platelet count.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-week history of progressive shortness of breath and intermittent cough with blood-tinged sputum. During this time, he has also noticed blood in his urine. He has no history of serious illness and does not take any medications. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 152/90 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows crackles at both lung bases. Urinalysis is positive for blood and results of a direct enzyme-linked immunoassay are positive for anti-GBM antibodies. The pathogenesis of this patient's disease is most similar to which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immunoglobulin A vasculitis (formerly known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura) is a type III hypersensitivity reaction involving the deposition of circulating IgA-immune complexes in the walls of small vessels throughout the body (e.g., skin, GI tract, joints, kidneys). Immune complex deposition does not play a significant role in the pathogenesis of Goodpasture syndrome, which this patient has.
Image Description:

Maculopapular, reddish, non-blanching, palpable skin lesions (purpura) are seen on both the distal right arm and leg. On the lower leg, the lesions are partially confluent and present with scaling and erosion.

B) INCORRECT:

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a type III hypersensitivity reaction involving immune complex deposition and typically affects small and medium-sized vessels throughout the body (e.g., skin, CNS, GI tract). Immune complex deposition is not a significant feature in the pathogenesis of Goodpasture syndrome, which this patient has.

C) INCORRECT:

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is a type III hypersensitivity reaction that involves the formation and deposition of immune complexes (IgM, IgG) and complement components in the glomerular basement membrane. Immune complex deposition is not a significant feature in the pathogenesis of Goodpasture syndrome, which this patient has.

D) CORRECT:

Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) is a type II hypersensitivity reaction involving IgG-mediated or IgM-mediated destruction of red blood cells. Its pathogenesis is similar to Goodpasture syndrome, which is also caused by a type II hypersensitivity reaction that involves the formation of autoantibodies against type IV collagen in the glomerular and alveolar basement membrane. In type II hypersensitivity reactions, tissue damage can occur due to complement-mediated cell lysis and/or cell-mediated cytotoxicity resulting from opsonization of macrophages and NK cells. Other examples of type II hypersensitivity reactions include acute hemolytic transfusion reactions, bullous pemphigoid, and pemphigus vulgaris.

See “Hypersensitivity classification” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction involving damage to the recipient's tissue by donor T cells. GvHD is an example of a cell-mediated (delayed) hypersensitivity reaction caused by sensitized T cells rather than the tissue-specific antibody formation seen in Goodpasture disease.
questions.hint: Dyspnea, cough, hemoptysis, hematuria, and anti-GBM antibodies on direct enzyme-linked immunoassay suggest Goodpasture syndrome, a type of pulmonary-renal syndrome.
